name: FELA KUTEE  "Music of Many Colours"
description: This Fela Kutee-shirt coincides with the FELA BUZZ - By the beginning of the eighties, Fela Anikulapo Kuti and Roy Ayers had already reached the peaks of their careers. Ayers found his style by migrating from Jazz's strict discipline to his unmistakable blend of jazz, soul and funk while Kuti created a new musical genre : Afro-Beat by updating African music's sound with American funk (James Brown) influences. Music fans must have frantically anticipated the coming together of the two maestros on this "Music of Many Colours" that features the co-produced "2000, blacks got to be free" and "Africa-Centre Of The World". The music is dashingly brillant : Fela's afro centrist groove completely rejuvenates Ayers' take on American Soul and R&B. You can't help being taken over by the vindicative tone and musical tornado of this LP.

name: FELA KUTEE 'Sorrow Tears & Blood'
description: Sorrow, Tears and Blood (1977) accurately depicts the trail left in the wake of the February 18, 1977, raid by 1,000 armed Nigerian army men on Fela Kuti and his Kalakuta republic. The price of the shirt reflects the year this LP was release.

name: FELA KUTEE & HIS LOS LOBITOS
description:
It's a shock to hear Fela Kuti, the furious, rabble-rousing godfather of Afro-beat, singing perky little high-life tunes about good times, but that's exactly what he did with his first band, Koola Lobitos, back in the mid-'60s. The first half of this set presents the band's hybrid of swinging London grooviness and African jazz, with Fela playing trumpet at least as much as he sings. In 1969, he took the band (renamed Nigeria 70) to Los Angeles.

The price of this tee shirt reflects the year the album was released

options.name: FELA KUTEE & HIS LOS LOBITOS S

name: FELA KUTEE 'Zombie'
description: In 1977 Fela and the Afrika '70 released the hit album Zombie, a scathing attack on Nigerian soldiers using the zombie metaphor to describe the methods of the Nigerian military. The album was a smash hit with the people and infuriated the government, setting off a vicious attack against the Kalakuta Republic, during which one thousand soldiers attacked the commune. Fela was severely beaten, and his elderly mother was thrown from a window, causing fatal injuries. The Kalakuta Republic was burned, and Fela's studio, instruments, and master tapes were destroyed. The price of the tee  reflects the year the album was released.
